answers.a: Ethyl maltol (E637) is a flavor enhancer that adds a sweet, caramel-like note to foods and beverages. It is permitted in many regions at low concentrations and is structurally related to maltol.
Typical food use levels are tiny—often 10 to 200 ppm (about 0.001–0.02%) depending on the application. Always follow local regulatory limits and formulation guidelines for your product type.

In DIY e-liquids, mixers commonly dissolve ethyl maltol crystals to make a 10% solution and then use 0.25–1% of that solution in the final mix (roughly 0.025–0.1% ethyl maltol). Do not exceed supplier recommendations and ensure ingredients are food grade.

answers.q: ejuice how to use ethyl maltol
answers.a: Dissolve the crystals in propylene glycol or ethanol to make a concentrated solution, then add drops to your base until the sweetness is balanced. Allow the e-liquid to steep and test in small batches to avoid muting other flavors.

It is the same flavoring molecule used as E637—a sweet, cotton-candy-like enhancer derived from maltol chemistry. Manufacturers use it to round out harsh notes in confectionery, beverages, and vaping liquids.
